awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the participation of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in the "2023 Riviere-Fabes Symposium" held April 28-30, 2023 at the University of Minnesota. The award gives early-career researchers, researchers who are members of underrepresented groups, and researchers without other sources of funding a chance to attend and participate in this conference.  
 
The symposium focuses on recent developments in Analysis, this year especially in the areas of harmonic analysis, fluid dynamics, singularity formation and sphere packing. More information can be found on the symposium web page https://cse.umn.edu/math/riviere-fabes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
This award sponsored the participation of young researchers in the annual Riviere-Fabes symposium in Analysis and PDE held at the University of Minnesota: a unique conference which comibines both scientific and educational components. Each year four prominent speakers from various branches of analysis and partial differential equations are invited to present two lectures each specifically tailored towards early career mathematicians. Thus young mathematicians are presented with an opportunity to learn cutting edge topics in analysis and PDE from the top experts in the field, helping educate and develop the next generation of analysts. Almost all US experts in analysis and PDE have at some point of their careers have attended this annual event.

This grant supported around 30 early career participants for the 2023 event and covered the housing costs of another 12 for the 2024 event (through a no cost extension). The 2023 symposium featured Xiumin Du (Northwestern),  Thomas Hou (Caltech), Danylo Radchenko (U Lille) and Jérémie Szeftel (Sorbonne U.). The 2024 symposium featured Zaher Hani (University of Michigan), Andrew Lawrie (MIT), Yumeng Ou (Upenn) and Vlad Vicol (NYU). The 2024 symposium also featured a poster session, allowing early career researchers to present their own work.

The list of topics covered in the 2023 and 2024 lectures touched upon many contemporary areas of analysis, partial differential equations, and adjacent fields, such as fluid dynamics, geometric measure theory, sphere packings, distance geometry, geometric flows, kinetic equations and many other modern and relevant topics, creating an excellent educational and scientific event.

 


Last Modified: 04/10/2025
Modified by: Max D Engelstein
